mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-1 MB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>Its a challenging time</strong> to be a semiconductor manufacturer. Wages and energy prices have been rising in traditionally low-cost manufacturing locations, while capital expenditures have increased. Meanwhile, competition is increasing, with many new companies entering the market over the past few years. Industry players are rightfully concerned about these developments and have been undertaking a record level of merger-and-acquisition activity, hoping to capture the next wave of productivity improvements.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What is Industry 4.0?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Industry 4.0 will introduce a new era of automated production and data exchange in factories. Under some definitions, the 4.0 in its name refers to the fact that it represents the fourth major disruption in modern manufacturing, following the lean revolution, increased outsourcing, and the first wave of automation. An alternative definition takes a longer-term view of manufacturing history, claiming that the first three disruptions involved the use of steam power, the discovery of electricity, and the introduction of computers in the workplace. In either case, Industry 4.0 represents a major advance that will change how we manufacture goods.</p>
<p>Industry 4.0 is a fairly recent innovation, and it wouldnt be possible without some recent technological advances: increased data volumes, computational power, and connectivity; the emergence of big data, analytics, and automated knowledge work; better human-machine interactions, such as those involving collaborative robots; and advanced production methods, including <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/3-d-printing-takes-shape">3-D printing</a> (exhibit).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/semiconductors/our%20insights/optimizing%20back%20end%20semiconductor%20manufacturing%20through%20industry%2040/svgz-optimizing-back-end-semiconductor-manufacturing-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Industry 4.0 results from four technologies that are disrupting the manufacturing sector." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/semiconductors/our%20insights/optimizing%20back%20end%20semiconductor%20manufacturing%20through%20industry%2040/svgz-optimizing-back-end-semiconductor-manufacturing-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Although Industry 4.0 techniques are relatively new to front-end fabs and almost unknown at back-end factories, weve already seen some impressive results. The availability of low-cost automation options and advanced robotics is making it easier for chip manufacturers to reduce human error or accelerate production. Likewise, the use of sensor-enabled equipment and big data analytics lets semiconductor companies predict when plant equipment may need to be repaired or replaced ahead of any breakdowns. And better connectivity among products and machines gives managers more visibility into production steps, which helps them detect and address potential errors earlier in the process.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>To remain competitive in this environment, front-end fabsthose that produce wafershave focused on improving operational efficiency through a combination of <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/next-frontiers-for-lean">lean programs</a> and <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/manufacturings-next-act">Industry 4.0</a> techniques. While lean initiatives are well known for their ability to reduce waste and promote continuous improvement, Industry 4.0 is an emerging concept that involves the increased digitization of the manufacturing sectoreverything from <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/getting-big-impact-from-big-data">big data analytics</a> to increased automation (see sidebar, What is Industry 4.0?).</p>
<p>Most back-end factories, which are primarily located in emerging markets, have not yet applied Industry 4.0 techniques to their major tasks, which include the dicing of wafers and the assembly, testing, and packaging of individual semiconductors. In fact, many of these facilities are still struggling to implement the lean techniques that are routine at front-end fabs. Even when back-end factories do achieve some benefits from lean programs, they often have difficulty sustaining improvement.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor-signup mck-o-sm-left-span mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-signup"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-7 DisruptorSignUp_mck-c-disruptor-signup__heading__JR4i0"><div>Stay current on your favorite topics</div></h2></div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-left"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/user-registration/register-mvc" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Subscribe</span></a></div></div>
<p>With cost pressures increasing, its time to reverse this situation. Our experience with 20 back-end factories in Asia shows that a more disciplined approach to lean, combined with the introduction of Industry 4.0 techniques, can help companies accelerate and sustain improvement in labor costs, throughput, and quality. Factories can typically realize productivity gains of 30 to 50 percent for direct labor and gains of 10 to 20 percent for maintenance productivity. They can also anticipate average improvement of 10 to 15 percentage points in overall equipment effectiveness (OEE), increases of 1 to 3 percent in yield, and a 30 to 50 percent decrease in customer complaints.</p>
<h2>Making the most of labor</h2>
<p>At back-end factories, operator touch timethat is, the amount of time an employee spends handling material or operating a machineaccounts for 30 to 50 percent of all labor. For the rest of the workday, employees are often idle while they wait for machines to finish their production cycle. Even if a line is not operating at full capacity, employee-to-machine ratios are fixed, which increases the amount of time that employees arent directly engaged in work.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/semiconductors/how-we-help-clients">Semiconductors Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>Some back-end factories have managed to improve labor productivity by applying standard lean techniques, such as adjusting worker-machine ratios based on operator touch time, or by introducing flexible staffing to ensure that the number of employees on the floor is appropriate for a factorys current capacity. These initiatives have produced some improvements, but theyre difficult to sustainand that means back-end manufacturing is still very labor intensive.</p>
<p>With labor costs continuing to escalate, its clear that back-end factories need to step up their lean programs. But they also need to consider Industry 4.0 solutions that can complement and support their efforts. For instance, some factories have equipped machines with sensors that monitor performance. In some cases, engineers analyze the data in a central control room and adjust process parameters as needed; in others, Industry 4.0 tools make the adjustments automatically (exhibit).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/semiconductors/our%20insights/optimizing%20back%20end%20semiconductor%20manufacturing%20through%20industry%2040/svgz-optimizing-back-end-semiconductor-manufacturing-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Remotely monitoring and adjusting machines from a central control room improves efficiency." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/semiconductors/our%20insights/optimizing%20back%20end%20semiconductor%20manufacturing%20through%20industry%2040/svgz-optimizing-back-end-semiconductor-manufacturing-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Industry 4.0 tools may be particularly helpful for some of a factorys most labor-intensive tasks, including the loading or unloading of machines, or final packaging. For instance, factories could use collaborative robots with camera-equipped hands to pick and place parts precisely. Since the robots incorporate <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/an-executives-guide-to-machine-learning">machine-learning technology</a>, employees can program them simply by moving the robot arms and hands to new positions.</p>
<p>In addition to automating many processes, Industry 4.0 tools make workers more effective at the tasks remaining under their remit. One tool, designed for maintenance staff, shows all actions these employees have completed related to a particular task, provides progress updates, and notes when problems have been escalated. The tool also captures photographs to supplement written reports, such as images of machines under repair.</p>
<h2>Taking a more thoughtful approach to throughput</h2>
<p>When assessing OEE, most back-end factories focus on absolute measures of uptimeequipment is either available or unavailableand ignore nuanced findings, such as minor stoppages that dont result in a complete shutdown. Whats more, back-end factories track production losses through a manual process that only identifies general trends over time. These high-level findings dont provide engineers with a detailed fact base about the factors contributing to production issues, making it difficult to craft improvement strategies.</p>
<p>Some back-to-lean basics are necessary to combat such problems. For instance, factories could create continuous-improvement teams to set priorities and identify the root cause behind throughput shortfalls. These teams are a fixture at many companies, but theyre far from universal at back-end plants. But lean improvements, by themselves, are not enough; factories also need to consider applying Industry 4.0 tools to accelerate the discovery and resolution of throughput issues.</p>
<p>Consider one straightforward innovation: machines could be equipped with sensors to record important events that affect OEE, including production slowdowns or equipment malfunctions. Operators would then use a touchscreen interface to enter contextual information, reducing the time spent on manual data input and providing engineers with a richer level of detail. More sophisticated Industry 4.0 solutions could take automation a step further by using problem-solving tools to examine machine-log data. These tools first analyze historical information and conduct automated data analyses to identify the root cause of problems. They then suggest solutions or automatically execute them.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Using the power of advanced analytics to improve manufacturing, R&D, and sales" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/semiconductors/our%20insights/improving%20the%20semiconductor%20industry%20through%20advanced%20analytics/using%20the%20power%20of%20advanced%20analytics%201536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Improving the semiconductor industry through advanced analytics</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/improving-the-semiconductor-industry-through-advanced-analytics" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Preventive maintenance, another essential element of efficient throughput, could benefit from Industry 4.0 tools that use <a href="/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/improving-the-semiconductor-industry-through-advanced-analytics">advanced analytics</a> to assess machine function in real time, with the goal of predicting failures before they occur. Typically, the tools collect information from multiple sources, rectifying any gaps or inconsistencies that might mar the analysis. They then search for patterns across multiple data sets, allowing them to create explanatory models and map performance drivers. With this information, engineers can create interventions that keep machines running.</p>
<h2>Enhancing quality without slowing the line</h2>
<p>If there are spikes or losses in yield, or unexpected quality issues at back-end factories, engineering teams must examine the machine data and speak to colleagues on the manufacturing line to identify the particular production steps that are causing losses. But engineers may collect the data only once a week, long after problems first arise, making it more difficult to identify root causes. Delays can be especially problematic if engineers need to interview production-line staff for information, since the workers may recall few relevant details about tool parameters or other operating conditions.</p>
<p>A better approach would involve establishing dedicated yield- and quality-improvement teams that have daily lean huddles. These structured conversations can help engineers understand issues related to the stability and variability of outputsknowledge that can drive improvements. The discussions will be even more valuable if participants receive insights from Industry 4.0 tools. Consider a few examples:</p>
<ul class="bulletList">
    <li><em>Yield tracking.</em> Analytical tools can generate automated yield reports that identify the major categories of quality rejects on each day of production, the reasons for product loss, and the machines or workstations where rejected units were processed. The information is quantifiedfor instance, the tools show the percentage of rejects associated with a particular machine or production problemand displayed on a dashboard in real time.</li>
    <li><em>Traceability throughout production.</em> Currently, back-end factories trace production units at the batch level, making it difficult to conduct detailed analyses that identify the specific source of quality problems. Industry 4.0 tools, by contrast, allow traceability at the individual-die level throughout production. Consider the case of a factory that was having serious issues with die cracks. Following traditional processes, engineers couldnt narrow down the source of problems or even determine whether the problems arose during front-end or back-end production. After applying Industry 4.0 tools, they could identify the front-end fab where rejected units originated, as well as all machines and operators involved in their manufacture.</li>
    <li><em>Root-cause analysis.</em> Once companies have compiled data on individual production units and obtained yield information, they can use Industry 4.0 tools to conduct sophisticated multivariate analyses. For instance, the company that was having trouble with die cracks analyzed quality outcomes for all possible tool paths. It then determined that wafers processed using a certain combination of machines were much more likely than others to have problems. Another multivariate analysis revealed that wafers manufactured at a particular front-end fab were more likely to be rejected. This information helped the factory design interventions that improved yield by 5 percent within four months.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The semiconductor industry is a leader in data collection; the problem is that companies use only a fraction of their information. Industry 4.0 tools can help factories mine their vast stores of knowledge for the first time, providing the detailed, practical insights needed to identify solutions. Equally important, Industry 4.0 tools automate many time-consuming tasks that back-end factories now complete manually. Together, these improvements help managers implement their lean programs more quickly and efficiently, with some companies capturing real improvement in costs, throughput, and quality within months. By leapfrogging over players who are taking a more traditional approach to lean, the back-end factories that embrace Industry 4.0 technologies may emerge as the winners in the increasingly competitive semiconductor sector.</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Optimizing back end semiconductor manufacturing through Industry 40","displayName":"Optimizing back end semiconductor manufacturing through Industry 40","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"529148cc-50cc-493a-b8c9-eaff06aa8f8c","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Optimizing back-end semiconductor manufacturing through Industry 4.0"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Can Industry 4.0 tools help back-end semiconductor factories capture elusive gains in productivity, throughput, and quality?"}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2017-02-16T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s a challenging time\u003c/strong\u003e to be a semiconductor manufacturer. Wages and energy prices have been rising in traditionally low-cost manufacturing locations, while capital expenditures have increased. Meanwhile, competition is increasing, with many new companies entering the market over the past few years. Industry players are rightfully concerned about these developments and have been undertaking a record level of merger-and-acquisition activity, hoping to capture the next wave of productivity improvements.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar What is Industry 4.0]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo remain competitive in this environment, front-end fabs\u0026mdash;those that produce wafers\u0026mdash;have focused on improving operational efficiency through a combination of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/next-frontiers-for-lean\"\u003elean programs\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/manufacturings-next-act\"\u003eIndustry 4.0\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;techniques. While lean initiatives are well known for their ability to reduce waste and promote continuous improvement, Industry 4.0 is an emerging concept that involves the increased digitization of the manufacturing sector\u0026mdash;everything from \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/getting-big-impact-from-big-data\"\u003ebig data analytics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to increased automation (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;What is Industry 4.0?\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost back-end factories, which are primarily located in emerging markets, have not yet applied Industry 4.0 techniques to their major tasks, which include the dicing of wafers and the assembly, testing, and packaging of individual semiconductors. In fact, many of these facilities are still struggling to implement the lean techniques that are routine at front-end fabs. Even when back-end factories do achieve some benefits from lean programs, they often have difficulty sustaining improvement.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp left]]\n\u003cp\u003eWith cost pressures increasing, it\u0026rsquo;s time to reverse this situation. Our experience with 20 back-end factories in Asia shows that a more disciplined approach to lean, combined with the introduction of Industry 4.0 techniques, can help companies accelerate and sustain improvement in labor costs, throughput, and quality. Factories can typically realize productivity gains of 30 to 50 percent for direct labor and gains of 10 to 20 percent for maintenance productivity. They can also anticipate average improvement of 10 to 15 percentage points in overall equipment effectiveness (OEE), increases of 1 to 3 percent in yield, and a 30 to 50 percent decrease in customer complaints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMaking the most of labor\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt back-end factories, operator touch time\u0026mdash;that is, the amount of time an employee spends handling material or operating a machine\u0026mdash;accounts for 30 to 50 percent of all labor. For the rest of the workday, employees are often idle while they wait for machines to finish their production cycle. Even if a line is not operating at full capacity, employee-to-machine ratios are fixed, which increases the amount of time that employees aren\u0026rsquo;t directly engaged in work.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eSome back-end factories have managed to improve labor productivity by applying standard lean techniques, such as adjusting worker-machine ratios based on operator touch time, or by introducing flexible staffing to ensure that the number of employees on the floor is appropriate for a factory\u0026rsquo;s current capacity. These initiatives have produced some improvements, but they\u0026rsquo;re difficult to sustain\u0026mdash;and that means back-end manufacturing is still very labor intensive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith labor costs continuing to escalate, it\u0026rsquo;s clear that back-end factories need to step up their lean programs. But they also need to consider Industry 4.0 solutions that can complement and support their efforts. For instance, some factories have equipped machines with sensors that monitor performance. In some cases, engineers analyze the data in a central control room and adjust process parameters as needed; in others, Industry 4.0 tools make the adjustments automatically (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit body text]]\n\u003cp\u003eIndustry 4.0 tools may be particularly helpful for some of a factory\u0026rsquo;s most labor-intensive tasks, including the loading or unloading of machines, or final packaging. For instance, factories could use collaborative robots with camera-equipped hands to pick and place parts precisely. Since the robots incorporate \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/an-executives-guide-to-machine-learning\"\u003emachine-learning technology\u003c/a\u003e, employees can \u0026ldquo;program\u0026rdquo; them simply by moving the robot arms and hands to new positions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to automating many processes, Industry 4.0 tools make workers more effective at the tasks remaining under their remit. One tool, designed for maintenance staff, shows all actions these employees have completed related to a particular task, provides progress updates, and notes when problems have been escalated. The tool also captures photographs to supplement written reports, such as images of machines under repair.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTaking a more thoughtful approach to throughput\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen assessing OEE, most back-end factories focus on absolute measures of uptime\u0026mdash;equipment is either available or unavailable\u0026mdash;and ignore nuanced findings, such as minor stoppages that don\u0026rsquo;t result in a complete shutdown. What\u0026rsquo;s more, back-end factories track production losses through a manual process that only identifies general trends over time. These high-level findings don\u0026rsquo;t provide engineers with a detailed fact base about the factors contributing to production issues, making it difficult to craft improvement strategies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome back-to-lean basics are necessary to combat such problems. For instance, factories could create continuous-improvement teams to set priorities and identify the root cause behind throughput shortfalls. These teams are a fixture at many companies, but they\u0026rsquo;re far from universal at back-end plants. But lean improvements, by themselves, are not enough; factories also need to consider applying Industry 4.0 tools to accelerate the discovery and resolution of throughput issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsider one straightforward innovation: machines could be equipped with sensors to record important events that affect OEE, including production slowdowns or equipment malfunctions. Operators would then use a touchscreen interface to enter contextual information, reducing the time spent on manual data input and providing engineers with a richer level of detail. More sophisticated Industry 4.0 solutions could take automation a step further by using problem-solving tools to examine machine-log data. These tools first analyze historical information and conduct automated data analyses to identify the root cause of problems. They then suggest solutions or automatically execute them.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003ePreventive maintenance, another essential element of efficient throughput, could benefit from Industry 4.0 tools that use \u003ca href=\"/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/improving-the-semiconductor-industry-through-advanced-analytics\"\u003eadvanced analytics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to assess machine function in real time, with the goal of predicting failures before they occur. Typically, the tools collect information from multiple sources, rectifying any gaps or inconsistencies that might mar the analysis. They then search for patterns across multiple data sets, allowing them to create explanatory models and map performance drivers. With this information, engineers can create interventions that keep machines running.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEnhancing quality without slowing the line\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf there are spikes or losses in yield, or unexpected quality issues at back-end factories, engineering teams must examine the machine data and speak to colleagues on the manufacturing line to identify the particular production steps that are causing losses. But engineers may collect the data only once a week, long after problems first arise, making it more difficult to identify root causes. Delays can be especially problematic if engineers need to interview production-line staff for information, since the workers may recall few relevant details about tool parameters or other operating conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA better approach would involve establishing dedicated yield- and quality-improvement teams that have daily lean \u0026ldquo;huddles.\u0026rdquo; These structured conversations can help engineers understand issues related to the stability and variability of outputs\u0026mdash;knowledge that can drive improvements. The discussions will be even more valuable if participants receive insights from Industry 4.0 tools. Consider a few examples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eYield tracking.\u003c/em\u003e Analytical tools can generate automated yield reports that identify the major categories of quality rejects on each day of production, the reasons for product loss, and the machines or workstations where rejected units were processed. The information is quantified\u0026mdash;for instance, the tools show the percentage of rejects associated with a particular machine or production problem\u0026mdash;and displayed on a dashboard in real time.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTraceability throughout production.\u003c/em\u003e Currently, back-end factories trace production units at the batch level, making it difficult to conduct detailed analyses that identify the specific source of quality problems. Industry 4.0 tools, by contrast, allow traceability at the individual-die level throughout production. Consider the case of a factory that was having serious issues with die cracks. Following traditional processes, engineers couldn\u0026rsquo;t narrow down the source of problems or even determine whether the problems arose during front-end or back-end production. After applying Industry 4.0 tools, they could identify the front-end fab where rejected units originated, as well as all machines and operators involved in their manufacture.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRoot-cause analysis.\u003c/em\u003e Once companies have compiled data on individual production units and obtained yield information, they can use Industry 4.0 tools to conduct sophisticated multivariate analyses. For instance, the company that was having trouble with die cracks analyzed quality outcomes for all possible tool paths. It then determined that wafers processed using a certain combination of machines were much more likely than others to have problems. Another multivariate analysis revealed that wafers manufactured at a particular front-end fab were more likely to be rejected. This information helped the factory design interventions that improved yield by 5 percent within four months.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe semiconductor industry is a leader in data collection; the problem is that companies use only a fraction of their information. Industry 4.0 tools can help factories mine their vast stores of knowledge for the first time, providing the detailed, practical insights needed to identify solutions. Equally important, Industry 4.0 tools automate many time-consuming tasks that back-end factories now complete manually. Together, these improvements help managers implement their lean programs more quickly and efficiently, with some companies capturing real improvement in costs, throughput, and quality within months. By leapfrogging over players who are taking a more traditional approach to lean, the back-end factories that embrace Industry 4.0 technologies may emerge as the winners in the increasingly competitive semiconductor sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"What is Industry 4.0"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIndustry 4.0 will introduce a new era of automated production and data exchange in factories. Under some definitions, the 4.0 in its name refers to the fact that it represents the fourth major disruption in modern manufacturing, following the lean revolution, increased outsourcing, and the first wave of automation. An alternative definition takes a longer-term view of manufacturing history, claiming that the first three disruptions involved the use of steam power, the discovery of electricity, and the introduction of computers in the workplace. In either case, Industry 4.0 represents a major advance that will change how we manufacture goods.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndustry 4.0 is a fairly recent innovation, and it wouldn\u0026rsquo;t be possible without some recent technological advances: increased data volumes, computational power, and connectivity; the emergence of big data, analytics, and automated knowledge work; better human-machine interactions, such as those involving collaborative robots; and advanced production methods, including \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/3-d-printing-takes-shape\"\u003e3-D printing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit sidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Industry 4.0 techniques are relatively new to front-end fabs and almost unknown at back-end factories, we\u0026rsquo;ve already seen some impressive results. The availability of low-cost automation options and advanced robotics is making it easier for chip manufacturers to reduce human error or accelerate production. Likewise, the use of sensor-enabled equipment and big data analytics lets semiconductor companies predict when plant equipment may need to be repaired or replaced ahead of any breakdowns. And better connectivity among products and machines gives managers more visibility into production steps, which helps them detect and address potential errors earlier in the process.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What is Industry
